instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P1V05S0_EN: What is P1V05S0_EN? P1V05S0_EN is a signal that enables the PP1V05_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.S4_PWR_EN: What is S4_PWR_EN? S4_PWR_EN turns on the S4 power rails. Signals ending in _EN enable whatever came before _EN in the signal name when the voltage of the signal is high. .
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3S3_EN: What is P3V3S3_EN? P3V3S3_EN is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.DDRREG_EN: What is DDRREG_EN? DDRREG_EN is an enable signal that turns on power rails for DDR memory.
definitions.P1V8S3_EN: What is P1V8S3_EN? P1V8S3_EN is a signal that enables the PP1V8_S3 line when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board has orange light on the charger, all the S5, S3 and S4 rails are present except <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL>
<CHIP>U8050</CHIP> gets <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> but <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS_FET_R</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> are missing
there is alsono short on the line

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> appears on S0 state; your board is stuck in S3, as you told...
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> goes high, or pulse at least?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is 3.32v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
That means your board is in S0 state.
So all the voltages controlled by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> should appear.
Check "S0 Enables" signals at page 59.
Be sure you get correct <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> first...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
thanks for your replay,
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_BUF_L</SIGNAL> = 3.30
<SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> = 3,30
<SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.30
<SIGNAL>P1V05S0_EN</SIGNAL> = 3,30

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message: Then all these power supplies mentioned should be present too; check that.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> 1,80
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 1.50
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0SZ_AUDIO_ADH</SIGNAL> 1,5
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.32
                                            <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 39.6 mili volt
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> 3,28
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET_R</SIGNAL>  3,28

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> 39.6 mili volt"
Is there short, or low value?
Post <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> voltages; you may need to change it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
I've replaced the <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> and
pin1 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_FET_R</SIGNAL> 3.02v
pin2 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.32V
pin3 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_FET_R</SIGNAL> 3.02v
pin4 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.32V
pin 6 <SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 3.32

I've replaced the <CHIP>U8050</CHIP> but nothing's changed I get
pin1/3 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS_FET_R</SIGNAL> 0.3v
pin 2/4 <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.32v
pin 6 <SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 0

I tried to bypass the SMC Sensor but the charger light changes from amber to green and again amber but the fan doesn't spin.
the fan is known working one and also there is no USB activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message: Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
yes I did. tried to bypass the SMC but the charger light changes from amber to green and again amber but the fan doesn't spin.
the fan is known working one and also there is no USB activity.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
I talk about SMC bypass, not SMC reset.
Use Google, is already explained in the forum how to do it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
all of the sudden the light on the charger is gone and <SIGNAL>SYSTEM_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> is dropped down to 0.8v but <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is present 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is. 3.37

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
Disconnect LIO flex and see if <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> goes high.
Don't forget to try SMC bypass!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
I tried to bypass smc by holding the power key for 10 second and connect the charger ( while keep pressing the power for the next 10 second ).
the board didn't power on but the light on the charger is back

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
Check voltage for all big coils.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes high, or pulse at least?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0,111v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message: Do you get any S3, or S0 voltages?

threads.message:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
Do you mean these voltages are present and steady?
Check all the voltages involved in <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> generation...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
yes sir these voltages are present.
Could you please explain a little more about the involved voltages in <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> geberation+

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
Look at page 59 of schematic.
There appear all the VMON and PGOOD signals which finally generate <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
If one of these signals misses, check the corresponding power supply...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
Thank you Sir for explanation,
p
<SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>S4_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>P3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL> is present
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is present
<TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>
pin1 <SIGNAL>VMON_Q1_BASE0</SIGNAL>,78v
pin3 0.11v
pin4 0,11v
pin5 <SIGNAL>VMON_Q2_BASE</SIGNAL> 0.00
pin6 <SIGNAL>S0_PGD_C</SIGNAL> 3,27v
pin7 <SIGNAL>VMON_Q3_BASE</SIGNAL> 0,70
pin 2 and 8 are unconnected according to the schematic but I measure 0.12v on them

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> is missing
threads.message:
"pin5 <SIGNAL>VMON_Q2_BASE</SIGNAL> 0.00"
Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>?
If present, check <RESISTOR>R8151</RESISTOR>/2/3 and <CAPACITOR>C8159</CAPACITOR>...
